import React from 'react'; import '../Duties.css'; import Navbar from './Navbar'; import Footer from './Footer'; export default function Duty9() { return ( <>

Fundamental Duty 9: Safeguard Public Property

Article 51A(i) - Protecting collective assets and promoting non-violence

üß© Comprehensive Understanding

Article 51A(i) establishes a dual obligation for citizens:

  • Positive Duty: To protect and preserve public property
  • Negative Duty: To renounce violence as a means of protest

This duty covers protection of:

  • Government buildings and infrastructure
  • Public transportation systems
  • Utilities and essential services
  • Cultural and historical monuments
  • Public educational institutions

üìñ Detailed Explanation

The constitutional and legal framework includes:

  • Legal Provisions:
    • Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984
    • Indian Penal Code Sections 425-440 (mischief and damage)
    • Compensatory jurisprudence for riot damages
  • Policy Mechanisms:
    • Guidelines for protest permissions
    • CCTV surveillance of sensitive installations
    • Community policing initiatives
  • Citizen Responsibilities:
    • Reporting vandalism and suspicious activities
    • Participating in neighborhood watch programs
    • Educating others about public property value

üìú Historical Context

This duty emerged from:

  • 1970s Political Turmoil:
    • Widespread destruction during Emergency protests
    • Railway and public transport vandalism
  • Constitutional Response:
    • 42nd Amendment (1976) during national security concerns
    • Swaran Singh Committee recommendations
  • Philosophical Foundations:
    • Gandhian principle of non-violent protest
    • Social contract theory of collective responsibility

üèõÔ∏è Judicial Interpretations

  • Destruction of Public Property Case (2009) : Established guidelines holding protest organizers liable for damages. [(2009) 5 SCC 212]
  • State of Gujarat v. High Court of Gujarat (1998) : Upheld compensation from rioters for public property damage. [AIR 1998 SC 3164]
  • Anita Thakur v. State of J&K (2016) : Balanced right to protest with duty to protect public property. [(2016) 15 SCC 525]

üîç Contemporary Challenges

  • Managing protests in digital/social media era
  • Preventing damage during mass agitations
  • Determining liability of political leaders
  • Protecting digital public infrastructure
  • Balancing dissent with civic responsibility
); }
